title: How to Protect Short Hair While Sleeping

steps.title: Traditional cloth pillowcases can make your hair frizzy.
steps.content: Traditional cloth pillowcases can make your hair frizzy. Silk pillowcases are very smooth, and don’t mess up your hair cuticles while you sleep. [1] X Research source Slip a silk pillowcase over your pillow instead to protect your short hair and prevent unwanted frizziness. [2] X Research source Satin pillowcases are also a great option.

steps.title: Silk wraps and bonnets protect your hair from tangling.
steps.content: Silk wraps and bonnets protect your hair from tangling. Wrap a silk scarf around your hair before heading to bed, or slip on a silk bonnet for more full coverage. Silk accessories are especially great if you have short, natural hair, which is delicate and more likely to tangle. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Regular cloth towels can frizz and break your hair.
steps.content: Regular cloth towels can frizz and break your hair. If you usually shower before bed, dry off your wet hair with a microfiber towel or old T-shirt instead. [4] X Research source These are a lot gentler, and won’t cause any damage. [5] X Research source Don’t rub your hair with the towel; instead, gently squeeze and blot away any excess water. [6] X Research source This trick is especially helpful if you have curly hair, as traditional towels can mess with your curl pattern. You may wake up with bed head if you go to sleep with wet hair. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Pick out a brush that works well with your hair type.
steps.content: Pick out a brush that works well with your hair type. Start brushing along the ends of your hair, working in small, gentle movements. To prevent breakage, slowly work your way up to the top of your hair. Brushes that have flexible bristles are great for fine, straight hair, while a widely-spaced paddle brush is best for thick, curly hair. A boar bristle brush is best for frizzy hair. A wet brush or pick comb is good for natural hair. Brush damaged or thinning hair with a synthetic-bristle brush.

steps.title: Dry shampoo
steps.content: Dry shampoo helps protect pixie cuts from potential bed-head. Grab your go-to can of dry shampoo and spray the ends of your hair. You don’t have to comb it in! The product prevents your strands from flipping out the next morning. [8] X Research source Dry shampoo also adds a bit of texture and volume to your hair.

steps.title: Argan and coconut oil moisturize and hydrate your hair overnight.
steps.content: Argan and coconut oil moisturize and hydrate your hair overnight. After hopping out of the shower, massage a dollop of argan or coconut oil through your damp hair. Leave the oil on overnight; in the morning, your hair will look and feel great! [9] X Research source Only use a small amount of oil, so the product doesn’t get all over your pillows and bedding. You don’t have to wrap your hair! These oils are jam-packed with proteins, and can protect your hair all on their own. This treatment works best if you shower before bed.

steps.title: Moisturize your hair so it doesn’t dry out.
steps.content: Moisturize your hair so it doesn’t dry out. Stop by your local beauty or hair supply shop and pick up a moisturizing mist. Spritz the product all over your hair, working from your roots to the ends. [10] X Research source Any moisturizing mist will work well for this! You don’t have to use a name-brand product.

steps.title: Bantu knots
steps.content: Bantu knots keep your curls defined overnight. Divide your hair into 8-10 different sections with a wide-tooth comb. Starting at the roots, twist each individual section of hair into a tight coil. Then, hold each knot in place with a bobby pin. [11] X Research source For extra protection, slip a silk bonnet overtop your knots before heading to bed.

steps.title: Pin curls
steps.content: Pin curls make your curls look softer. Grab and separate a single curl from the rest of your short hair. Then, loop the hair along your index finger. Slip the coil off your finger, flatten it against your head, and secure it with a bobby pin. Remove the bobby pins in the morning to create a bouncy, stylish look. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Loose braids
steps.content: Loose braids make it easier to sleep with a bob-style haircut. Starting a few inches or centimeters from the ends of your roots, tie several sections of hair into loose braids. [13] X Research source Then, spray a leave-in conditioner over your hair before heading to bed. Your hair will look textured and stylish in the morning! [14] X Research source
